title: Henderson Island Got the World's Highest Density of Plastic Pollution
body: The duo's analysis concluded that nearly 18 tons of plastic had piled up on the island—giving Henderson the highest density of plastic debris recorded anywhere in the world—at least so far.
readable_content:
- NationalGeographic (2023-12-08): How an Uninhabited Island Got the World’s Highest Density of Trash
  Henderson Island, lying in the South Pacific, has a shocking 38-million-piece accumulation of plastic trash. Despite being uninhabited, it is bombarded by plastic waste from all over the world due to ocean currents. The researchers, Jennifer Lavers and Alexander Bond, found that nearly 18 tons of plastic had piled up on the island, giving it the highest density of plastic debris recorded worldwide. This devastating discovery serves as a reminder of the alarming levels of plastic pollution in our oceans.
summary:
The shocking accumulation of plastic trash on Henderson Island is a stark reminder of the devastating impact of plastic pollution in our oceans. It underscores the urgent need for global action to address this environmental crisis. The high density of plastic debris found on the uninhabited island highlights the far-reaching consequences of plastic waste and the importance of tackling this issue on a global scale.
